thread.title: Why Samsung's Troubles Are Apple's iPhone Gains - Fortune
thread.title_full: Why Samsung's Troubles Are Apple's iPhone Gains - Fortune

posts.title: Why Samsung's Troubles Are Apple's iPhone Gains - Fortune
posts.text:
© 2016 Time Inc. All rights reserved. Why Samsung’s Troubles Are Apple’s iPhone Gains 
Apple’s iPhone had its strongest market share gains in two years at the end of October, new research shows. 
The iOS device accounted for 40.5% of all smartphone sales in the U.S. during the three-month period ended October, according to data released on Wednesday by Kantar Worldpanel ComTech. That was up from 33.5% share of smartphone sales during the same period in 2015, according to the research firm. That’s the strongest year-over-year growth Apple AAPL has witnessed in the last two years and the greatest number of sales share since the three-month period ended January 2015. 
Android devices still reign supreme in the U.S., collectively accounting for nearly 58% of all smartphone sales. Get Data Sheet , Fortune’s technology newsletter 
While the iPhone is still trailing Android devices, Apple’s success during the period might have been due in part to the troubles Samsung endured during the same period. 
In August, Samsung released the Galaxy Note 7 in hopes of competing against the iPhone 7 that would launch in September. However, the smartphone fell victim to manufacturing troubles that caused it to overheat and in some cases, explode. After a recall, replacement devices suffered from the same problem, leading Samsung to discontinue the handset . The Galaxy Note 7 had been expected by some industry watchers to sell exceedingly well. Apple could have benefited from that. 
Still, there’s more to the iPhone’s success during the period than Samsung . Kantar’s consumer insight director Lauren Guenveur noted that the iPhone 7 proved exceedingly popular. The analyst said in a statement that the smartphone’s “lack of the headphone jack has proved to be a non-issue for U.S. iPhone consumers.” Apple’s iPhone 7 was the top-selling smartphone during the period. 
In addition, Guenveur said Apple benefits from being Apple. For more about Apple iPhone, watch: 
“While Android dominates in terms of the raw number of devices it powers, Apple remains the most desirable smartphone brand in the world,” the analyst said. 
Moving away from Apple, Kantar noted that Google’s Pixel smartphone, the first to be designed and engineered by Google GOOGL , accounted for 0.5% of all smartphone sales during the three-month period ended October. That put Google’s handset on equal footing with smartphones from popular competing brands, like China-based Huawei.

thread.title: Apple's iPhone Manufacturing Probably Won't Leave China for the U.S., but Other Products Might
thread.title_full: Apple's iPhone Manufacturing Probably Won't Leave China for the U.S., but Other Products Might - TheStreet

posts.author: Eric Jhonsa
posts.title: Apple's iPhone Manufacturing Probably Won't Leave China for the U.S., but Other Products Might
posts.text:
When a company's financial interests clash with a vocal political effort to get the company to change its ways, it's probably best not to make firm predictions about what's going to ensue. All the same, in the case of Donald Trump's push to get Apple ( AAPL ) to move iPhone production to the U.S., there are good reasons to think that most, if not all, iPhone production won't be leaving China anytime soon.
There could be greater wiggle room for some other Apple products, however.
Though Apple has officially maintained it has no plans to move iPhone production anywhere, a couple of recent stories raise some questions. Last month, Japan's Nikkei reported Apple asked iPhone contract manufacturers Foxconn and Pegatron -- both are based in Taiwan, and rely on Chinese manufacturing plants -- in June to explore the possibility of making iPhones in the U.S.
Pegatron reportedly declined the request due to cost concerns. Foxconn, which gets over half its sales from Apple, agreed to launch a study, but the Nikkei adds Foxconn chairman Terry Gou wasn't enthusiastic about the idea.
Regardless, Foxconn disclosed on Wednesday that it's "in preliminary discussions regarding a potential investment that would represent an expansion of our current U.S. operations." The remarks come a day after a document carried by Masayoshi Son, the CEO Japanese tech/telecom giant SoftBank, during a meeting with Trump appeared to suggest Foxconn is planning to invest $7 billion in U.S. and create 50,000 jobs along the way.
Apple is a holding in Jim Cramer's Action Alerts PLUS Charitable Trust Portfolio . Want to be alerted before Cramer buys or sells AAPL? Learn more now .

posts.author: Tom Ensey
posts.title: iPhone 8 rumors predict wireless charging, better cameras
posts.text:
(RNN) - Only three months after the release of Apple's latest phone, rumors are already exploding about the bigger, brighter, sexier iPhone 8.
The best of the bunch: Apple will finally include wireless charging capability, ending all those maddening moments when your battery fizzled and you were nowhere near an electrical outlet.
U.S. sales of the iPhone 7 have been great, Business Insider reported. Despite initial outrage over the removal of the headphone jack, iPhone 7 was the best-selling phone in the nation and, along with iPhone 7 Plus, accounted for almost 16 percent of all smartphone sales. 
That has not diminished dozens of leaks and rumors of the wonderful iPhone 8 yet to come, with astonishing new features and a complete redesign. The glass-backed marvel might be part of a three-product release if the scuttlebutt is true. 
MacRumors  on Dec. 7 cited Japanese website Mac Otakara's report that Apple would release models 7s and 7s Plus with no redesign, but available in a a new, bright red color and powered by a faster A11 chip.
If that's the case, iPhone 8 will be a top-of-the line option for high rollers who want the latest tech whatever it costs.
Other reports say the Home button will go away, and along with fingerprint ID it will be integrated into the edge-to-edge curved screen.
But the game-changing upgrade would address sketchy battery life, the bane of iPhone users.
The iPhone 8 will at last include wireless charging, according to multiple reports  Macrumors said that Hon Hai Precision Industry is already manufacturing recharging modules, so that your phone will recharge constantly as long as it is in range of the device.
The iPhone 8 is said to be 8.8 inches with OLED (Organic light-emitting diode). The 7s models will feature TFT-LCD (Thin-film transmitter liquid-crystal display). One will be 4.7 inches and the other 5.7 inches. Some rumors say the larger TFT-LCD model also will have wireless charging, but the reports conflict. All the models will have glass backs.
The phones will feature an improvement to the telephoto lens in the iPhone 7, which has optimal stabilization for the macro lens but not the zoom.
